tit.e: Sun (A Length Unit in The East Asian System of Weights And Measures)

sen.j: 寸（すん）は、尺貫法における長さの単位である。
sen.e: "Sun" is a length unit in the traditional East Asian system of weights and measures.
sen.cmt: （注①）・・・「尺貫法」は、広義では（日本に限らず）東アジア一帯で用いられる度量衡の単位系です。本ファイルでは日本・中国双方の「寸」が検討されていることを考えると、ここも広義であると解されます。（注②）・・・「寸」は度量衡の単位として現在も使用されていますので、動詞も現在形にしています。

sen.e: "Sun" is the reading of the Chinese character of 寸 by its Chinese-derived pronunciation, and its pronunciation peculiar to Japanese is "ki."

sen.j: 日本では明治時代に1尺＝(10/33)メートル(m)と定められたので、1寸は(1/33)メートル、すなわち約3.03センチメートル(cm)となる。
sen.e: In Japan, during the Meiji period, 1 shaku was set at 10/33 meter, so 1 sun became 1/33 meter, or about 3.03 centimeters.

sen.j: また、国際単位系のデシメートル(dm)にも「寸」の字を宛てており、区別のため尺貫法（市制 (単位系)）の寸を「市寸」、SI（公制）の寸を「公寸」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: And in China, the Chinese character 寸 is used also for the decimeter (dm), which belongs to International Unit System (SI), and so, to make a distinction, the sun used in their traditional system of measurement is called "shi cun," and the sun used in SI is called "gong cun."

sen.j: 当初の寸は親指の幅を指す身体尺であったと考えられている（これはインチも同様である）。
sen.e: Sun is, just the same as "inch," thought to have originated from an anthropomorphic unit for showing the breadth of a thumb.

sen.j: 尺は親指と人差指を広げた時の幅であり、元々の寸は尺とは独立に発生したものと考えられるが、周代に尺の10分の1とされるようになった。
sen.e: Shaku originated from the breadth between the thumb and forefinger when they are opened, and sun seems to have been invented independently from shaku, but anyway, sun began to be set at the length of a tenth shaku during the age of Zhou dynasty China.

sen.e: And during the age of Han dynasty China, the breadth of a grain of proso millet was set at 1 "bu," (in pinyin, 'fen') and 10 bu was equalized with 1 sun.

sen.j: 尺の長さが変わっても常に1尺＝10寸という関係は保たれた。
sen.e: Varied as the length of shaku from time to time, the ratio of 1 to 10 was kept.

sen.j: 手の象形の左に横線を引いたものが「寸」という文字の元々の形である。
sen.e: The pictogram of a hand with a horizontal line in its left became the Chinese character 寸.
The original shape of the Chinese character '寸' is the hieroglyphic of a hand with a horizontal line in its left.

sen.j: これは、手首に親指を当てて脈拍を計る様子を形取ったものであり、そこから親指の幅を指す現在の寸の意味になったという。
sen.e: This character represents the shape that a thumb is counting somebody's pulse by feeling the wrist, which is said to lead to the character's present meaning of the breadth of a thumb.

sen.j: また、『説文』には「人の手をへだてること一寸、脈拍これを寸口といふ」という記述があり、ここから、手の平の下端から1寸の位置で脈を計るため、「寸」の文字がこの長さを表すようになったとする説もある。
sen.e: And "Setsumon" (Analytical Dictionary of Chinese Characters) says, "Go 'a bit' (in Chinese characters, 一寸) from the lower end of the palm, and you will find 'sunko' (the place where the pulse can be felt)," and some say this was why 1 寸 began to be equalized with the length from the lower end of the palm to sunko.
sen.cmt: （注①）・・・『説文』の中の「一寸」は長さではなく、（このファイルの最後にも出てくる）「ちょっと」の意味で使われていると解されます。そう解さないと、この記述が「一寸」の長さの由来だ、という話が堂々巡りになります。（注②）・・・「寸口（すんこう）」とは「手首の脈所」を指します。
sen.e: Some says the description in "Setsumon" (Analytical Dictionary of Chinese Characters) that 'Go a bit (in Chinese characters, 一寸) from the lower end of the palm, and you will find sunko (寸口, the place where the pulse can be felt)' led the character '寸' to indicate the length.

sen.j: 日本では、成人男性の身長はおおむね5尺台（約150 cm - 180 cm）であったので、身長を言う時には「5尺」を省略してその下の寸だけを言った。
sen.e: In Japan, most adult men had the height from 5 shaku (about 150 centimeters) to 6 shaku (about 180 centimeters), so when their height was explained, 5 shaku was omitted from their real height, and merely the remainder was mentioned in sun.

sen.j: 「寸法」という言葉もあるように「長さ」の意味でも用い、「寸劇」「寸志」「寸評」「寸断」「一寸（ちょっと）」など、短いこと、わずかなことの意味にも用いる。
sen.e: As the Japanese word "sunpo" (length) shows, "sun" is used as the prefix that means length itself, and "sun" is also used as the prefix or suffix that means "short," "small," or the like, which is seen in some Japanese words, such as "sungeki" (a short play), "sunshi" (literally, a small token of one's gratitude, which is used as a humble expression by a gift sender), "sunpyo" (a brief comment), "sundan" (cutting something into shreds), and "chotto" (in Chinese characters, 一寸, which means "for a while," "a little," or the like).
sen.cmt: （注①）・・・「ちょっと」の部分はローマ字（chotto）だけでは「寸」との関係が伝わらないので漢字を併記しました。（注②）・・・「の意味で用い」の部分は「の意味を持つ接頭辞（接尾辞）として用い」の意味に解しています。
